name: iron(III) chloride production, product in 40% solution state | iron(III) chloride, without water, in 40% solution state | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/4814/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of iron(III) chloride (active substance). The inventory refers to a commercial aqueous solution with a concentration of 40 wt % iron(III) chloride by weight. This equals an iron concentration of 14% by weight in the solution. Raw materials, auxilliaries, energy consumption and emissions are estimated from personal communication with two iron(III) chloride producers and literature data.  Infrastructure is included with a default value.  ;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

From the reception of scrap iron at the factory gate. The iron(III) chloride solution is produced from scrap iron, spent pickling acids, hydrogen chloride and chlorine. 

This activity ends with the production of aqueous iron(III) chloride. Process electricity demand included. No fuel for process heat included due to exothermal process. No credits given for possible heat export. Land use and infrastructure of plant only roughly included.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data valid for production processes used in Switzerland.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Commercial production of iron(III) chloride solutions in Switzerland is mainly based on dissolving iron in hydrochloric acid and oxidizing the resulting iron(II) chloride with chlorine. In this process also spent pickling acid solutions containing iron(II) chloride are used as chlorine and iron source.;In 1994, the production output (as 100% FeCl3) in Europe was estimated to 150'000 t FeCl3 per year. For Switzerland the consumption of 40% iron(III) chloride solution will account for about 20-25'000 t per year which equals 8-10'000 t FeCl3 (100%) per year.;Commercial forms of iron(III) chloride include sublimed anhydrous iron(III) chloride (99% FeCl3), iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (ca. 60% FeCl3), and iron(III) chloride solution (ca. 40% FeCl3). The major commercial form is a solution with 40 wt % FeCl3. For this inventory only the 40% iron(III) chloride solution was investigated. It was assumed that the main supply for Switzerland is produced within Switzerland and therefore imports were neglected.;Iron(III) chloride solutions are prepared by dissolving iron in hydrochloric acid and oxidizing the resulting iron(II) chloride with chlorine. In a continuous, closed-cycle process, iron(III) chloride solution is reduced with iron and the resulting iron(II) chloride solution is reoxidized with chlorine. In about 80% of the iron(III) chloride production in Switzerland, spent pickling acids are used as additional iron source. In average 92% of the iron used for iron(III) chloride production in Switzerland origins from iron scrap and only about 8% has pickling acid as iron source. Only few process data were available for the production of iron(III) chloride operating without pickling acid use. Therefore the same emissions and wastes were applied as for the process using pickling acids. The data presented in this inventory represent an average production process for iron(III) chloride in Switzerland. A simplified process scheme of iron(III) chloride production is shown below.;Reference:;Ullmann (2001) Iron Compounds, Iron Choride, Iron(III) Chloride, Chapter 2.1. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Sixth Edition, June-2001 Electronic Release (ed. Wildermuth E., Stark H., Silver J. and Rituper R.). 6 th Electronic Release Edition. Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under: http://www.mrw.interscience.wiley.com/ueic/ull_search_fs.html
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Investigated share on consumtion in Switzerland estimated to about 80%.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data for resources, energy, water use, wastes and water emissions based on producer in Switzerland. Further data from literature used for energy demand. Infrastructure only rougly estimated with a proxy-process.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=CH
Iron(III) chloride is an almost black crystalline solid. Iron(III) chloride is very soluble in water. The solution is red to yellowish-brown, aqueous and odourless. Iron(III) chloride irritates the skin and especially eyes. The aqueous solution is strongly acidic.

The largest use of iron(III) chloride (around 90%) is in the form of dilute solutions that are employed as flocculating and precipitating agents in water treatment. According to data from the U.S. municipal wastewater treatment accounts for 59%, municipal potable water treatment for 22% and industrial water treatment for 8% of the consumption. Further uses of iron(III) chloride (11%) include electronic and photographic etchants, metal surface treatment, catalysts and uses as a chlorinating and oxidising agent.

Source:
ChemExpo (2000) Chemical Profiles: Ferric Chloride, November 2000. Retrieved 21.11.2001 from <http://www.chemexpo.com/news/PROFILE001127.cfm>.

exchanges.description: Estimation. Calculated average from data from the producers.

Estimation.   The production process produces sludge due to impurities in the scrap iron and the pickling acids. This sludge has a high content of water, carbon and metals. Most of this sludge is disposed of in an underground deposit in Germany.

Estimated from one large producer.

It was assumed the emissions were released into a river.

Estimation. Calculated average from data from the producers. It was assumed that the chlorine used for the process is separated before the liquefaction step and is therefore supplied in the gaseous form. The chlorine is assumed to be produced using membrane cell technology, which is the predominant technology used for producing chlorine (IHS Markit, 2018).

Reference:
IHS Markit (2018) Chlorine/Sodium Hydroxide (Chlor-Alkali) (https://ihsmarkit.com/products/chlorine-sodium-chemical-economics-handbook.html, accessed on the 2018-06-27).
